title: Exercise One - Face value
scenarioTemplate: Practice rapid first-impression interpretation from card imagery without overthinking.
flowSteps: Draw one card and describe only what is visibly happening.
Name the first practical meaning in one to two sentences.
Compare one alternative interpretation and choose the strongest fit.
Ask for a hint only if you feel stuck.
bookSummary: This opening drill trains immediate visual reading before textbook keywords. You describe what is plainly on the card, then translate that into a practical message without overloading the interpretation.

stepPlan.text: Draw one card and describe only what is visibly happening.
Name the first practical meaning in one to two sentences.
Compare one alternative interpretation and choose the strongest fit.
Ask for a hint only if you feel stuck.

title: Exercise 1A - Looking beyond face value
scenarioTemplate: Move beyond literal imagery into symbolic patterns and implied action.
flowSteps: Draw a card and list the literal visual facts first.
Infer symbolic subtext: motive, timing, or emotional tone.
Compare literal and symbolic reads side by side.
Pick the interpretation that best matches context.
bookSummary: This follow-up asks you to move from literal scene description into symbol, atmosphere, and implication. The goal is to keep the read grounded in imagery while still reaching deeper meaning.

stepPlan.text: Draw a card and list the literal visual facts first.
Infer symbolic subtext: motive, timing, or emotional tone.
Compare literal and symbolic reads side by side.
Pick the interpretation that best matches context.

title: Exercise Two - Me and you
scenarioTemplate: Contrast two perspectives to build empathy and role awareness in readings.
flowSteps: Draw two cards: one for you and one for the other person.
Describe each card from its assigned perspective.
Swap viewpoints and reinterpret each card.
Summarize what changes when perspective shifts.
bookSummary: This exercise develops relational reading by separating perspectives. You practice distinguishing your own lens from another person's position, then deliberately swapping viewpoints.

stepPlan.text: Draw two cards: one for you and one for the other person.
Describe each card from its assigned perspective.
Swap viewpoints and reinterpret each card.
Summarize what changes when perspective shifts.

title: Exercise Three - Exactly what do you two have in common anyway?
scenarioTemplate: Find shared symbols between cards quickly and consistently.
flowSteps: Draw two cards and scan for immediate common symbols.
Name one common thread in plain language.
Explain how that shared thread changes interpretation.
If no clear commonality appears, compare symbols again before moving on.
bookSummary: This drill looks for shared visual threads between cards to improve synthesis speed. Instead of reading each card in isolation, you identify common motifs and infer what they jointly emphasize.

stepPlan.text: Draw two cards and scan for immediate common symbols.
Name one common thread in plain language.
Explain how that shared thread changes interpretation.
If no clear commonality appears, compare symbols again before moving on.

title: Exercise Four - From here to there
scenarioTemplate: Read cards as progression from state A to state B.
flowSteps: Draw two cards as current state and destination.
Describe what must change between the two.
Name likely friction in the transition.
End with one actionable bridge step.
bookSummary: This sequence reads movement from current state to destination. You focus on transition, obstacles, and actionable bridging rather than static card meanings.

stepPlan.text: Draw two cards as current state and destination.
Describe what must change between the two.
Name likely friction in the transition.
End with one actionable bridge step.

title: Exercise Five - There and back again
scenarioTemplate: Use three-card sequencing to compare forward and reverse narrative flow.
flowSteps: Draw three cards and read left to right.
Read the same cards right to left.
Compare how chronology changes the meaning.
Choose the direction that best fits the question.
bookSummary: This exercise trains narrative direction. You read the same three-card line in both directions to see how sequence changes emphasis and storyline.

stepPlan.text: Draw three cards and read left to right.
Read the same cards right to left.
Compare how chronology changes the meaning.
Choose the direction that best fits the question.

title: Exercise Six - Birds of a feather
scenarioTemplate: Group-card pattern recognition across three-card clusters.
flowSteps: Draw three cards and identify repeating motifs.
Classify common traits (element, motion, mood, value).
Infer the shared thread in a single concise sentence.
Test the thread against one concrete scenario.
bookSummary: This pattern-recognition drill identifies repeating elements across a cluster. You group cards by motif and test whether the shared thread holds under context.

stepPlan.text: Draw three cards and identify repeating motifs.
Classify common traits (element, motion, mood, value).
Infer the shared thread in a single concise sentence.
Test the thread against one concrete scenario.

title: Exercise Seven - Hey! What does THIS card mean?
scenarioTemplate: Clarify a difficult card using aspecting or clarification cards.
flowSteps: Pick one difficult card as your target.
Draw up to three clarification cards around it.
Explain how each clarifier modifies the target card.
State one final interpretation with confidence level.
bookSummary: This clarification method deepens one difficult card by surrounding it with supporting cards. The emphasis is controlled expansion: clarifiers should illuminate, not distract.

stepPlan.text: Pick one difficult card as your target.
Draw up to three clarification cards around it.
Explain how each clarifier modifies the target card.
State one final interpretation with confidence level.

title: Exercise Eight - One plus one equals what?
scenarioTemplate: Blend paired card energies into a single coherent statement.
flowSteps: Draw two cards and interpret each one separately.
Combine both into one integrated message.
Try one alternate blend and compare clarity.
Keep the strongest combined interpretation.
bookSummary: This blend exercise fuses two card messages into one coherent statement. The practice goal is integration without flattening each card's distinct contribution.

stepPlan.text: Draw two cards and interpret each one separately.
Combine both into one integrated message.
Try one alternate blend and compare clarity.
Keep the strongest combined interpretation.

title: Exercise Nine - One plus one plus one equals what?
scenarioTemplate: Scale card blending from pairs to triples while preserving clarity.
flowSteps: Draw three cards and choose an anchor card.
Blend the other two cards around the anchor.
Produce one concise combined interpretation.
Refine wording until the statement is contradiction-free.
bookSummary: This scales pair blending to three-card synthesis. You preserve structure by anchoring the trio and then integrating supporting cards around that anchor.

stepPlan.text: Draw three cards and choose an anchor card.
Blend the other two cards around the anchor.
Produce one concise combined interpretation.
Refine wording until the statement is contradiction-free.

title: Exercise Ten - The never-ending story
scenarioTemplate: Build a continuing narrative by chaining card transitions.
flowSteps: Draw an initial three-card sequence and define the storyline premise.
Add three more cards one by one to extend the narrative.
Maintain continuity and clear cause-effect links.
Pause and summarize the major turning point.
bookSummary: This storytelling drill builds continuity across expanding sequences. You start with a base line, extend it card by card, and keep causal coherence in the evolving narrative.

stepPlan.text: Draw an initial three-card sequence and define the storyline premise.
Add three more cards one by one to extend the narrative.
Maintain continuity and clear cause-effect links.
Pause and summarize the major turning point.

title: Exercise Eleven - Something to look at
scenarioTemplate: Deep visual observation drill to sharpen symbolic noticing.
flowSteps: Draw one card and inspect fine visual details.
Describe color, direction, posture, and implied motion.
Translate those visual cues into reading meaning.
Compare with a familiar reference card from memory and note the key contrast.
bookSummary: This visual-discipline exercise slows the read down to details you might normally skip. The intent is to train symbolic noticing so interpretations are evidence-based, not generic.

stepPlan.text: Draw one card and inspect fine visual details.
Describe color, direction, posture, and implied motion.
Translate those visual cues into reading meaning.
Compare with a familiar reference card from memory and note the key contrast.

title: Really Advanced Exercises
scenarioTemplate: High-complexity synthesis drills combining patterning, sequencing, and clarifiers.
flowSteps: Define a complex scenario with multiple constraints.
Draw up to six cards and add clarifiers only where truly needed.
Track dominant patterns and card-to-card aspects.
Deliver a structured interpretation with practical next steps.
bookSummary: These advanced drills combine sequencing, clarification, and cross-card patterning under tighter constraints. The goal is controlled complexity: structure first, then nuance.

stepPlan.text: Define a complex scenario with multiple constraints.
Draw up to six cards and add clarifiers only where truly needed.
Track dominant patterns and card-to-card aspects.
Deliver a structured interpretation with practical next steps.
